Epstein-Files Declassified Documents Archive

Epstein New York Flights: Aviation Records of NYC Operations

New York was the epicenter of Jeffrey Epstein's operations. His Manhattan mansion at 9 East 71st Street and regular flights from area airports formed the backbone of his activities. The flight logs document thousands of movements through New York airspace, revealing patterns of travel and connections to the city's elite.

Teterboro Airport: Epstein's Hub

Most of Epstein's flights originated from Teterboro Airport in New Jersey, just across the Hudson River from Manhattan. This private aviation facility was ideal for Epstein's needs - discrete, efficient, and accustomed to wealthy clients. Flight logs show hundreds of departures and arrivals at Teterboro over the years. The airport's minimal commercial traffic and private terminals offered the privacy Epstein required.

Manhattan Mansion Connection

Epstein's Manhattan mansion at 9 East 71st Street was his primary residence and the destination for many of his New York flights. The 40-room townhouse, one of the largest private residences in Manhattan, served as both home and headquarters. Flight records show patterns of travel that correlate with events and visitors to the property.

New York Flight Patterns

Analysis of the flight logs reveals distinct patterns in Epstein's New York travel. Weekday flights often went to Florida or Washington DC, while weekend trips frequently headed to the Caribbean or Europe. The logs also document emergency and unscheduled flights, sometimes at unusual hours. Flight durations varied from short hops to international journeys.

High-Profile New York Passengers

New York's concentration of wealth and power meant many high-profile individuals appeared in Epstein's flight logs. The passenger manifests include names from finance, politics, entertainment, and academia. Many of these passengers were traveling to or from events in New York. The logs became evidence in investigations examining the extent of Epstein's network.

Flight Crew and Staff

The New York flight operations employed a regular crew of pilots and flight attendants. Several of these individuals later provided testimony about what they observed during flights. Their accounts, combined with the flight logs, painted a picture of operations that raised serious concerns. Some crew members reported seeing young women on flights and unusual behavior.
New York's flight records form the core of Epstein's aviation history. The frequency of flights from Teterboro and connections to his Manhattan mansion reveal how central the city was to his operations. These logs remain crucial evidence in understanding the full scope of Epstein's activities and network.
